Synset.Definition: a motive for living
a motive that can be defended by reasoning or logical argument
a rational motive for a belief or action
Synset.Example: the reason that war was declared

Synset.Definition: grounds
Synset.Example: don't do it on my account
the paper was rejected on account of its length
he tried to blame the victim but his success on that score was doubtful

Synset.Definition: the cause or intention underlying an action or situation, especially in the phrase `the whys and wherefores'
a positive motivational influence
an efficient incentive
Synset.Example: they hoped it would act as a spiritual dynamic on all churches

Synset.Definition: a negative motivational influence
a motivation that is inconsistent with reason or logic
an instinctive motive
(psychology) an urge to withdraw or avoid a situation or an object
(psychology) an urge to accept or approach a situation or an object
(psychoanalysis) an unconscious urge to die
a strong spontaneous and irrational motivation
Synset.Example: the mass media and advertisers channel our irrational impulses

Synset.Definition: an urge to do or say something that might be better left undone or unsaid
Synset.Example: he felt a compulsion to babble on about the accident

Synset.Definition: an irrational but irresistible motive for a belief or action
an intense desire to be alone or out in the open
an intense persistent desire to drink alcoholic beverages to excess
an intense and irresistible love for yourself and concern for your own needs
an irresistible impulse to steal in the absence of any economic motive
pathologically excessive (and often incoherent) talking
a mania restricted to one thing or idea
an irresistible sexual attraction to dead bodies
an irresistible desire to pick at superficial body parts (as in obsessive nail-biting)
an uncontrollable desire to set fire to things
an irresistible urge to pull out your own hair
very strong or irresistible impulse to travel
an irrational motive for performing trivial or repetitive actions, even against your will
Synset.Example: her compulsion to wash her hands repeatedly

Synset.Definition: obsession with a particular word which the person uses repeatedly or which intrudes into consciousness
motivation based on ideas of right and wrong
the pursuit of pleasure as a matter of ethical principle
motivation deriving logically from ethical or moral principles that govern a person's thoughts and actions
an inner voice that judges your behavior
a motivating awareness of ethical responsibility
a divine presence believed by Quakers to enlighten and guide the soul
an actuating force or factor
something that incites or provokes; a means of arousing or stirring to action
any incitement to action
Synset.Example: he awaited the signal to start
the victory was a signal for wild celebration

Synset.Definition: (psychoanalysis) psychic energy produced by the libido
(psychoanalysis) the libidinal energy invested in some idea or person or object
Synset.Example: Freud thought of cathexis as a psychic analog of an electrical charge

Synset.Definition: (psychoanalysis) a lack of cathexis; a condition in which significant objects or memories arouse no emotion in an individual
